data.body: G.S. Ohm discovered a fundamental law concerning current flow in 1828, predating the understanding of the underlying physical mechanisms. Consider a conductor with a current $I$ flowing through it and let $V$ represent the potential difference across its ends. Ohm's law states that:

data.name: paragraph
data.body: where $R$, the resistance of the conductor, is a constant of proportionality. The SI unit of resistance is the ohm (\(\Omega\)). The resistance $R$ not only relies on the material of the conductor but also its dimensions. To understand the dependence on dimensions, envision a conductor in the form of a slab with length $l$ and cross-sectional area $A$. Now, consider placing two identical slabs side by side, doubling the length but keeping the cross-sectional area constant. The resistance of this combination, $R_c$, is double that of a single slab due to the doubling of length, demonstrating that resistance is proportional to length ($R \propto l$).

data.name: paragraph
data.body: Now, imagine dividing the slab into two equal parts, each having half the original cross-sectional area. Each half-slab would have double the resistance of the original, indicating that resistance is inversely proportional to cross-sectional area ($R \propto \frac{1}{A}$).
